photo.description: Segovia is a very old city in Spain. Famous for its cathedral and its bi-millenium aqueduct which is in a very good shape. Here is a view of stairs lighten and contrasted by the shadow of its impressive Roman building. I liked patterns emerging from this shot in black and white, I hope you like it too. Best rendered in bigger.

photo.description: The Aqueduct of Segovia (or more precisely, the aqueduct bridge) is a Roman aqueduct and one of the most significant and best-preserved ancient monuments left on the Iberian Peninsula. It is the foremost symbol of Segovia, as evidenced by its presence on the city's coat of arms [Wikipedia]. HDR from five bracketed exposures (1EV step) on a tripod. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- El Acueducto de Segovia es la obra de ingeniería civil romana más importante de España y uno de los monumentos más significativos y mejor conservados de los que dejaron los romanos en la península Ibérica. Se trata probablemente del símbolo más importante para los habitantes de Segovia, hasta el punto de figurar en su escudo [Wikipedia]. HDR generado de un horquillado de cinco exposiciones (paso de 1EV) sobre trípode.

photo.description: The Romans built this aqueduct some time around 100 A.D.. It is 728 m (2,392 ft) long and 28 m (92 ft) above street level. It still functions as part of the city's water supply, though water is now carried in cast iron pipes in the aqueduct's channels..

photo.description: Reproducción de la estatua de la diosa Luperca amamantando a Rómulo y Remo. La estatua original en los Museos Capitolinos de Roma. Esta copia fue donada por Roma a la ciudad de Segovia en 1974, coincidiendo con el bimilenario del formidable acueducto romano de esa capital castellana. La estatua se encuentra ubicada precisamente tras el acueducto. The Capitoline Wolf Copy of the statue of the goddess Luperca suckling Romulus and Remus. The original statue is in the Capitoline Museums in Rome. This copy was donated by Rome to the city of Segovia in 1974, coinciding with the second millennium of the formidable Roman aqueduct of the Castillian capital. The statue is located just behind the aqueduct.
photo.title: La Loba Capitolina

photo.description: Monumento a Rómulo y Remo, fundadores de Roma, y a la legendaria Loba Capitolina que les amamantó. La estatua fue regalada por Roma a la ciudad de Segovia (Castilla y León, España), ante cuyo acueducto se sitúa hoy en día. El monumento fue inaugurado el 20 julio de 1974. Es la copia de una estatua de bronce etrusco del siglo V antes de Cristo, conservada en los Museos Capitolinos de Roma. Capitoline Wolf Monument to Romulus and Remus, founders of Rome, and the legendary Capitoline Wolf that suckled them. The statue was given by Rome to the city of Segovia (Castilla y León, Spain), at whose aqueduct stands today. The monument was inaugurated on July 20th 1974. It is a copy of an Etruscan bronze statue of V century BC, preserved in the Capitoline Museums in Rome.
photo.title: Loba Capitolina

photo.description: For some reason every time I see this photo I think of working in this building tossing and flipping pizza dough... Probably the Roman & Italian influence even though this is Spain!!
photo.tags: aqueduct pizza roman archeology segovia spain espana europe europa travel españa
photo.title: Pizzas

photo.description: With a lot of help from the locals. Segovia prides itself on maintaining its aqueduct. It was under repair when we visited in 1993. Without the pride locals have in maintaining it, the aqueduct would be nothing more than ruins.
photo.tags: roman aqueduct archeology segovia spain espana europe europa travel españa
photo.title: Withstanding the Test of Time
